title: The Future of Energy Storage
text: The global transition to renewable energy sources presents unique challenges due to the intermittent nature of solar and wind power. As we move away from fossil fuels, the need for efficient and reliable energy storage solutions becomes increasingly critical. This post explores how lithium-ion batteries are playing a pivotal role in this transition and their potential to revolutionize our energy systems.

title: The Future of Energy Storage
text: The global transition to renewable energy sources presents unique challenges due to the intermittent nature of solar and wind power. As we move away from fossil fuels, the need for efficient and reliable energy storage solutions becomes increasingly critical. This post explores how lithium-ion batteries are playing a pivotal role in this transition and their potential to revolutionize our energy systems.

title: The Future of Energy Storage
text:
The Challenge of Intermittency
Renewable energy sources like solar and wind are inherently variable:

Solar power generation drops at night and during cloudy weather
Wind power fluctuates based on atmospheric conditions
Both can experience seasonal variations in output

This intermittency creates a fundamental mismatch between energy supply and demand, potentially leading to grid instability and reliability issues. Energy storage provides the solution to this challenge by:

Storing excess energy during high production periods
Releasing stored energy during low production or high demand periods
Smoothing out fluctuations to maintain grid stability

title: The Future of Energy Storage
section: Lithium-ion Technology: Current State and Future Potential
text:
Lithium-ion Technology: Current State and Future Potential
Lithium-ion batteries have emerged as the leading technology for grid-scale energy storage due to their:

High energy density
Decreasing costs (over 90% reduction in the past decade)
Improving cycle life and performance
Scalability from residential to utility applications

Recent advancements in lithium-ion technology have addressed many early concerns about cost, lifespan, and safety. Current research focuses on:

Improving energy density through new cathode and anode materials
Extending cycle life to match the 20+ year lifespan of renewable installations
Enhancing safety features and thermal management
Reducing dependency on rare or geopolitically sensitive materials

title: The Future of Energy Storage
text:
Optimizing Battery Storage Systems
My research at Plaksha University focuses on developing strategies to optimize battery storage deployment and operation. Key aspects include:

Strategic Sizing
Properly sizing battery systems is crucial for cost-effectiveness. Our work applies large deviations theory to determine optimal storage capacity that balances reliability and economic considerations.


Intelligent Control
Advanced reinforcement learning algorithms can optimize battery charging and discharging cycles, maximizing both battery lifespan and economic value through:

Energy arbitrage (buying/storing when prices are low, selling when high)
Grid services provision (frequency regulation, voltage support)
Peak demand reduction
Renewable integration support



Shared Battery Resources
Our research on statistical economies of scale in battery sharing demonstrates that communities can achieve significant cost savings through shared battery resources compared to individual installations.

title: The Future of Energy Storage
text:
Conclusion
Lithium-ion batteries represent a critical enabling technology for our renewable energy future. While challenges remain, the rapid pace of technological improvement and cost reduction suggests that widespread deployment of energy storage will accelerate in the coming years. As researchers continue to optimize these systems, we move closer to a sustainable, reliable, and efficient clean energy grid.
I welcome your thoughts and questions on this topic. Feel free to reach out via the contact page to discuss further.

title: The History of Artificial Intelligence
text: Attempting to systematically study the history of any human endeavour is an intellectual hurdle which hides in it a humoungous potential and bears through it a sweet fruit of truth. Such an activity bears flexibility of thought, it sows seeds for lays bare detailed insights and more than any other benefit, it gives strength. But this activity is difficult. To attempt a study of a subject’s evolution is difficult. This more than any other subject, is more so the case with Artificial Intelligence which by its nature spans and crosses so many disciplines that in my opinion no other subject pursuid by humans does. The reason for this is clear. Artificial Intelligence begins at the inate experience of every human being. It starts with that hopelessness of reasoning the experienced reality and ends today at the most colourful intersection of most advanced of human technologies. It crosses border between disciplines, by approach from nueroscience, philosophy and in application from mathematics to biology. Thus it is a tremendous task to attempt studying the history of such an intricate subject. Am I attempting to do such a thing? I do not know. Right now not. Right now, the following document only contains the most curious of happenstances and outlines the outline of the developments of a Giant of a human endeavour. Right now, the following documents only contains an Outline of the evolution of the field of Artificial Intelligence.

title: The History of Artificial Intelligence
text:
Brief Remarks on the Outline
Key Decisions Made:

Precursors Section: The structure from [the-wikipedia-article] revealed I had underemphasized the rich mythological and fictional foundations of AI. So, I have updated outline now with ancient myths (Greek Talos, Jewish Golem), medieval legends, and modern fiction that shaped AI imagination.
Periodization: [the-wikipedia-article] refined the chronology of the Outline. The “Birth of AI” period (1941-1956) now properly includes wartime computing advances, and I’ve separated the later periods more clearly.
Institutional Context: The details from [the-lesswrong-blog]. I have added more sections about specific research centers and their approaches (Stanford logic, MIT anti-logic, Edinburgh), which provides important context for understanding how different AI schools of thought developed.
Market and Commercial Aspects: [the-wikipedia-article] emphasizes the commercial dimension thourougly. I’ve now included in the outline sections for details about AI companies, market cycles, and the business side of AI development.
Recent Recognition: I’ve added a section on 2024 Nobel Prizes - it shows AI’s achievement of scientific respectability and recognition at the highest levels.

Structural Decisions Worth Noting:

Wikipedia uses broader periods with more overlap, while my original outline was more strictly chronological
Wikipedia emphasizes the cyclical nature of AI development (winters and booms) more explicitly
The Wikipedia structure shows how AI “went behind the scenes” during winters, continuing to develop within other fields
Recent developments are given more weight, reflecting AI’s current prominence

Depth vs Breadth Trade-offs:
Right now, the outline maintains more technical depth in areas like specific algorithms and theoretical foundations, while [the-wikipedia-article] structure is more accessible to general readers. For the article, I am considering audience targeting to decide on the appropriate level of technical detail for each section.
Finally here is the Outline:

title: Dr. Vivek Deulkar
text:
Research Focus
My work centers on developing innovative solutions for:

Managing uncertainties in renewable energy through advanced battery storage systems
Applying Reinforcement Learning and Machine Learning to energy optimization
Exploring sustainable and carbon-efficient energy systems
Integrating theoretical frameworks from Classical Electromagnetics and Weber’s Electrodynamics

title: Dr. Vivek Deulkar
text:
Professional Experience
Prior to joining Plaksha University, I conducted postdoctoral research at the Manning College of Information and Computer Sciences, University of Massachusetts Amherst, where I focused on developing AI-driven solutions for sustainable energy systems.
I am currently affiliated with the Indorama Ventures Center for Clean Energy at Plaksha University, contributing to research on sustainable carbon-efficient energy systems.

title: Research
text:
My research focuses on addressing critical challenges in sustainable energy through the integration of advanced computational techniques and energy storage solutions. My primary areas of interest include:


I develop strategies to effectively manage the inherent uncertainties in renewable energy sources through optimized battery storage systems. This research aims to enhance grid reliability while maximizing the utilization of clean energy resources.



I apply sophisticated Reinforcement Learning and Machine Learning techniques to solve complex challenges in energy systems, including:

Energy arbitrage optimization
Predictive modeling for renewable energy generation
Adaptive control strategies for heterogeneous battery systems
Decision-making under uncertainty for energy management




Working with the Indorama Ventures Center for Clean Energy at Plaksha University, I explore comprehensive approaches to developing sustainable, carbon-efficient energy solutions that can be scaled and implemented in real-world settings.



My research is grounded in strong theoretical foundations, including:

Classical Electromagnetics
Weber’s Electrodynamics
Stochastic modeling and applied probability
Sequential decision-making and optimization
Control theory

title: Research
text:
Current Projects

Optimal Battery Storage Management for Renewable Integration
This project focuses on developing advanced algorithms for sizing and managing battery storage systems to reliably integrate renewable energy sources into the grid. We use large deviations theory and stochastic optimization to address the variability and uncertainty in renewable generation.


AI-Driven Energy Arbitrage
We are developing reinforcement learning algorithms to optimize energy trading decisions in electricity markets, with particular attention to battery-equipped renewable generators. This research explores the potential economic benefits of energy storage while supporting grid stability.


Decarbonization Through Flexible Loads
Building on my postdoctoral research, this project quantifies and enhances the decarbonization potential of flexible loads in residential buildings, contributing to more sustainable energy consumption patterns.

title: Teaching
text:
Teaching Philosophy
My teaching approach emphasizes:

Connecting Theory to Practice: Bridging theoretical concepts with real-world applications to enhance student understanding and motivation.
Interactive Learning: Encouraging active participation through discussions, problem-solving sessions, and practical assignments.
Research Integration: Incorporating cutting-edge research findings into course content to expose students to the latest developments in the field.
Interdisciplinary Perspectives: Highlighting connections between electrical engineering, computer science, economics, and environmental studies to foster holistic understanding of energy systems.
